intro: Alpinia paradoxa, commonly known as the "Clove Ginger," is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Zingiberaceae family, which includes gingers and turmeric. The plant is characterized by its tall, slender stems and large, lance-shaped leaves that can grow up to 1 meter in length. Its flowers are typically orange or red and are borne in inflorescences at the top of the plant. Alpinia paradoxa is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has some traditional medicinal uses.
